trial_identification.scientifictitle: Single-dose Pregabalin in Postoperative Pain Relief after Minor Gynaecological Surgery

interventions.interventions: Single-dose pregabalin 100 mg administered 1-2 hours pre-operatively, effect on postoperative pain assessed.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain as assessed by visual analogue scale.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately postoperatively and at 1, 2 and 24 hours.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain on movement and score for cramping pain also assessed.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately postoperatively and at 1, 2 and 24 hours.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Total dose of fentanyl used intraoperatively and in recovery.
Total doses of other analgesics used postoperatively.
Presence of side effects of pregabalin: headache, lightheadedness, drowsiness, ataxia, visual disturbance.
Modified Brief Pain Inventory Short Form

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Undergoing minor gynaecological surgery on uterus/cervix without skin or mucosal incision, i.e. D&C +/- Hysteroscopy. ASA 1 or 2.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Allergy to pregabalin.History of chronic pelvic pain.Receiving preoperative misoprostol.Currently taking opioids or other forms of pain relief, sedatives or anticonvulsants.Preoperative history of dizziness or severe headaches.Petient request for sedative/anxiolytic premedication.

trial_design.concealment: Numbered containers of drug or placebo (identical capsules), randomised and prepared by pharmacy. Double blinded until all patients recruited and assessment finished.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: King Edward Memorial Hospital 374 Bagot Road Subiaco Perth WA 6008

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Women undergoing D&C surgery often experience pain afterwards between 2 and 7 on a scale of 1-10. This pain is intially due to surgical trauma but may continue because of resulting inflammation. If the ongoing cycle of inflammation is reduced pain may be less. Pregabalin is a treatment for seizure disorders. It also has pain relieving and calming properties. It can reduce local tissue inflammation and the release of pain mediators. Therefore pregabalin given preoperatively may reduce postoperative pain.
